docs.lead_paragraph: If not for the suture laced with metal staples that runs the length of her sternum, Roseann Errante of Hauppauge would have looked like any woman who gave birth to triplets 10 days ago: happy and relieved as she clutched the hand of her husband, Joseph. But the Errantes were celebrating nine weeks early, their every smile and sigh being captured by television cameras and reporters, after Ms. Errante underwent a rare combination of operations: a Caesarean section followed by open-heart surgery, to save her babies' lives and then her own.

headline.main: A Mother's Medical Drama Ends in Babies and Smiles

docs.snippet: STONY BROOK, N.Y., Aug. 29 - If not for the suture laced with metal staples that runs the length of her sternum, Roseann Errante of Hauppauge would have looked like any woman who gave birth to triplets 10 days ago: happy and relieved as she clutched...

docs.lead_paragraph: On Sunday evening, Matthew Koso tipped three ounces of formula into his 4-day-old daughter's mouth, then hoisted her atop his shoulder in hope of a burp. On Tuesday morning, he is scheduled to be arraigned on charges for which the newborn is the state's prime piece of evidence. Mr. Koso is 22. The baby's mother, Crystal, is 14. He is charged with statutory rape, even though they were wed with their parents' blessing in May, crossing into Kansas because their own state prohibits marriages of people under 17.

headline.main: In Nebraska, Rape Charge Follows Legal Marriage, in Kansas, to 14-Year-Old

docs.abstract: Matthew Koso of Falls City, Neb, is being charged with statutory rape of 14-year-old girl, even though they were wed with parents' blessing months before girl, Crystal, gave birth to their child; couple crossed into Kansas because Nebraska prohibits marriages of people under 17; Kosos, who had learning problems in school and was discharged from Marine Corps after four months, is 22 and has known Crystal since they both were young children; couple and their newborn are living with his parents; outrage over case ripples through state; Atty Gen Jon Bruning's office is deluged with letters, vast majority angrily urging that he leave couple alone; experts say it is extremely rare for man to be prosecuted for statutory rape when he has married his minor partner; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A man who crossed into Kansas to marry a 14-year-old girl is being charged with statutory rape in Nebraska.

byline.original: By JODI WILGOREN; Gretchen Ruethling contributed reporting from Chicago for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''From Delivery Room to Bedroom'': From a young age when women learn the facts of life, they are astonished at how unfair pregnancy and birth are. Women are left to experience the physical process entirely on their own. Sympathetic partners can do little to help (and there are plenty who aren't even sympathetic), the very least of which is being present if the woman requests it.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''From Delivery Room to Bedroom'': From a young age when women learn the facts of life, they are astonished at how unfair pregnancy and birth are. Women are left to experience the physical process entirely on their own.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sitting at the gateway of the nation's capital, Cité Soleil is a broiling slum of shacks, dust and ditches filled with human waste. It is home to several hundred thousand people who now live with virtually no government services, no police and only an occasional helping hand from international aid groups. Yet, with the first round of national elections now scheduled for Nov. 13, what happens in Cité Soleil is increasingly important to the world beyond its squalor. Not only does it have one of the biggest blocs of potential voters -- many of whom back Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the ousted president -- but it also can generate the kind of violence that could disrupt those elections.

headline.main: A Haitian Slum's Anger Imperils Election Hopes

docs.abstract: Cite Soleil, sprawling slum on outskirts of Port-au-Prince, is key to Haiti's national elections scheduled for Nov 13; it has one of biggest blocs of potential voters--many of whom back ousted president Jean-Paul Aristide--and can generate kind of violence that could disrupt elections; international peacekeepers, wearing flak jackets and driving armored personnel carriers, now conduct no regular patrols in its densely populated neighborhoods; 400 United Nations troops entered slum on July 6 and ended up in five-hour gun battle with gangs who control area; neighborhood leaders of party founded by Aristide, who blame international community and particularly United States for Aristide's departure, accuse UN troops of indiscriminate killings; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Residents of Cité Soleil could use votes or violence to sway the national elections.

multimedia.credit: During a recent visit to Cité Soleil, New York Times reporters and a Discovery Times Channel crew toured the squalid living conditions with local leaders. The leaders said innocent residents were shot and killed in a recent gunfight between U.N. troops and gang members. The U.N. said they had received reports that some of the casualties were caused by gang members who used residents as shields. The U.N. also cited reports that gang members had executed residents after the gun battle.
multimedia.caption: A Visit to the Largest Slum in Haiti

The leaders said innocent residents were shot and killed in a recent gunfight between U.N. troops and gang members. The U.N. said they had received reports that some of the casualties were caused by gang members who used residents as shields. The U.N. also cited reports that gang members had executed residents after the gun battle.
